message_1:
Find the value of the complex line integral:

$$\oint_C \frac{\sin(z)}{z^2 + 4z + 3}dz$$

where $C$ is the circle $|z-1| = 2$ traversed in the counterclockwise direction.
message_2:
To evaluate the complex line integral, we first need to find the poles of the integrand inside the contour $C$. The integrand is given by:

$$f(z) = \frac{\sin(z)}{z^2 + 4z + 3}$$

The denominator can be factored as:

$$z^2 + 4z + 3 = (z+1)(z+3)$$

So, the poles of $f(z)$ are at $z=-1$ and $z=-3$. Since the contour $C$ is the circle $|z-1|=2$, only the pole at $z=-1$ is inside the contour.

Now, we will use the residue theorem to evaluate the integral. The residue theorem states that:

$$\oint_C f(z)dz = 2\pi i \sum_{k=1}^n \text{Res}(f, a_k)$$

where $\text{Res}(f, a_k)$ is the residue of $f(z)$ at the pole $a_k$. In our case, we have only one pole inside the contour, $z=-1$. To find the residue at this pole, we can use the formula for simple poles:

$$\text{Res}(f, -1) = \lim_{z \to -1} (z+1) f(z)$$

Substituting $f(z)$:

$$\text{Res}(f, -1) = \lim_{z \to -1} (z+1) \frac{\sin(z)}{(z+1)(z+3)}$$

The $(z+1)$ term cancels out:

$$\text{Res}(f, -1) = \lim_{z \to -1} \frac{\sin(z)}{z+3}$$

Now, we can evaluate the limit:

$$\text{Res}(f, -1) = \frac{\sin(-1)}{-1+3} = \frac{\sin(-1)}{2}$$

Now, we can use the residue theorem to find the value of the integral:

$$\oint_C f(z)dz = 2\pi i \cdot \frac{\sin(-1)}{2} = \pi i \sin(-1)$$

So, the value of the complex line integral is:

$$\oint_C \frac{\sin(z)}{z^2 + 4z + 3}dz = \pi i \sin(-1)$$
